Verbs

Verbs represent actions, events, or states of being. They are the most important part of a sentence because they tell us what is happening. In Filipino, verbs are called pandiwa.

Base Form of Verbs

The base form of verbs is used in creating the different tenses of verbs which will be discussed below. Examples of base form are "run", "eat", and "sleep". These verbs correspond to "takbo", "kain", and "tulog", respectively, in Filipino.

Activity 1: Active Recall for Base Form of Verbs

For this activity, we shall look at the base form of verbs and their Filipino translation. We use the base form to create the different tenses of verbs which will be discussed below. You can choose to randomize the ordering and hide the Filpino translations to test yourself.

Image

English Word

Filipino Translation

Drink

Inom

Activity 2: Translate It On Your Own (Base Form of Verbs)

For this activity, we will be translating English verbs in base form to Filipino. Don't worry, the input box is case-insensitive. You can also switch to Filipino-to-English and back!

English Word

Filipino Translation

Drink

Verb Tense

Verbs can be conjugated in different tenses. The tense of a verb tells us when the action happens. The three main tenses are the past tense, present tense, and future tense. In Filipino, these equate to Pangnagdaan, Pangkasalukuyan, at Panghinaharap.

I. Pangnagdaan - Past Tense

The past tense is used to describe actions that have already happened. In Filipino, the past tense is formed by adding nag- to the beginning of the root word. For example, the root word luto means "to cook". Adding nag- to the beginning of the root word gives us nagluto, which means "cooked".

The past tense is also formed by adding -um- to the beginning of the root word after the first consonant. For example the root word talon means "to jump". Adding -um- after the first consonant gives us tumalon, which means "jumped". This also happens with inom which means "to drink". However, there is no consonant in the beginning of the word, so the past tense form is uminom, which means "drank".

Some verbs use -in- instead of -um- to form the past tense. For example, the root word buhat means "to carry". Adding -in- after the first consonant gives us binuhat, which means "carried".

Activity 3: Active Recall for Past Tense of Verbs

For this activity, we shall look at the past tense of verbs and their Filipino translation. You can choose to randomize the ordering and hide the Filpino translations to test yourself.

Image

English Word

Filipino Translation

Drank

Uminom

Activity 4: Translate It On Your Own (Past Tense of Verbs)

For this activity, we will be translating English verbs in past tense to Filipino. Don't worry, the input box is case-insensitive. You can also switch to Filipino-to-English and back!

English Word

Filipino Translation

Drank

II. Pangkasalukuyan - Present Tense

The present tense is used to describe actions that are happening now. In Filipino, the present tense is formed by adding nag- to the beginning of the root word and repeating the first syllable. For example, the root word luto means "to cook". Adding nag- to the beginning of the root word and repeating lu gives us nagluluto, which means "is cooking"/"cooks".

The same pattern occurs with the other verbs, we duplicate the first syllable and use the affix for the past tense form. For example, the past tense form of inom is uminom. Adding um- to the beginning of the word after repeating i gives us umiinom, which means "is drinking"/"drinks".

The same goes for the word takbo, which means "to run". First we duplicate the first syllable ta to result in tatakbo. Then we add -um- after the first consonant to result in tumatakbo, which means "is running"/"runs".

Activity 5: Active Recall for Present Tense of Verbs

For this activity, we shall look at the present tense of verbs and their Filipino translation. You can choose to randomize the ordering and hide the Filpino translations to test yourself.

Image

English Word

Filipino Translation

English Word

Filipino Translation

Drinks

III. Panghinaharap - Future Tense

The future tense is used to describe actions that will happen in the future. In Filipino, the future tense is formed by adding mag- to the beginning of the root word and repeating the first syllable. For example, the root word luto means "to cook". Adding mag- to the beginning of the root word and repeating lu gives us magluluto, which means "will cook".

Some verbs don't use an affix at all and just repeat the first syllable. For example, the root word inom means "to drink". Repeating i gives us iinom, which means "will drink".

Activity 7: Active Recall for Future Tense of Verbs

For this activity, we shall look at the future tense of verbs and their Filipino translation. You can choose to randomize the ordering and hide the Filpino translations to test yourself.

Image

English Word

Filipino Translation

Will drink

Iinom
